results.title: May's early days
results.creator_credit: Robyn Colls, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Through Robyn’s tribute to the life and experiences of her mother, May, she gives us some insight of a spirited woman and her connection with the region in which she grew up.

results.title: Maximum security
results.creator_credit: Mark Stiles and Prisoners' Action Group
results.brief_description: This film describes life in the “intractable” section of a maximum security jail based on prisoners’ actual accounts. The “tracs” sections are notorious jails inside the jails, totally isolated from the outside world and beyond the reach of the law and of public scrutiny. A work funded through the Experimental Film and Television Fund.

results.title: Maximum effort
results.creator_credit: Philip Dorte, John Elliot and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “War in the Air”.
The beginning of Britain’s strategic air bombardment of Germany, related to its effect on the German war effort, Spring, 1941-Spring 1942. Title music by Sir Arthur Bliss. Music for this film by Malcolm Arnold.

results.title: Max Stephens talks about frameworks
results.brief_description: Max Stephens addresses a meeting at Horsham in June 1987 to explain the stage of development that the Curriculum frameworks project had then reached. The program outlines the basis and approach to learning emphasised by the Frameworks project and also looks at the implementation of tasks. No other credits available.

results.title: Max Harris
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
As a founder of the “Angry Penguins”, Max Harris was at the forefront of the modernist movement in Australian poetry. He recalls the ferment in the artistic community as writers, painters and musicians struggled to find an authentic Australian voice and the uproar surrounding the Ern Malley controversy. Harris remembers his friendship with Sydney Nolan and the journey they made together which inspired the artist to paint his Ned Kelly series. A poet, author, publisher and social commentator, Max Harris gives a unique overview of a vital period in Australian cultural history.

results.title: Max et les Ferrailleurs = Max and the Scrap Merchants
results.creator_credit: Claude Sautet, Raymond Danon and Ralph Baum
results.brief_description:
Max is a cop obsessed with catching criminals ‘in the act’. After a few misfortunes, he turns his attention to small time criminals. Abel, a childhood friend of Max is running a scam with a gang of metal scrappers. Unbeknownst to Abel, Max becomes acquainted with his girlfriend Lily, a prostitute. For Lily, Max becomes Felix, a rich bank manager and a regular client. Slowly, Felix/Max feeds Lily information about his bank in order to incite Abel and his gang to commit a failsafe hit.

Credits: Producers, Ralph Baum, Raymond Danon ; director, Claude Sautet ; writers, Claude Neron, Jean-Loup Dabadie, Claude Sautet ; photography, Rene Mathelin ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Romy Schneider, Michel Piccoli, Bernard Fresson, Francois Perier, Georges Wilson, Bobby Lapointe, Michel Creton, Dany Jacquet, Betty Beckers, Philippe Leotard.

results.title: Max Ernst: journey into the subconscious
results.brief_description: The inner world of painter, Max Ernst, is the subject of this film. One of the principal founders of Surrealism, Max Ernst explores the nature of materials and the emotional significance of shapes to combine with his collages and nether-world canvasses.

results.title: Max Ernst
results.creator_credit: Peter Schamoni, RM Arts and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Traces the history of renowned painter and sculptor, Max Ernst, his personal life as well as artistic career. The program contains extensive interviews and commentary from Ernst himself which details the pattern of his life and work from his founding influence in the Surrealist movement, throughout World War II and his struggles within and without Germany up to his settlement in America and then move back to Europe. Opening with an outline of the commencement of the Dada movement in 1919, the program discusses the life history of Ernst from his move to Paris before World War II and his association and friendship with Paul Eluard along with other founding members of the Surrealist group. The details of his artistic interests in natural history made strange, that is, the confusion of disparate beings and objects in nature through mind and poetic associations, are discussed in terms of his public work as well as that undertaken in more personal spaces such as murals in friends houses and sculptures and exterior murals adorning his own various residences. With the advent of Hitler’s power in Germany, his works as a mirror to a ‘mad time’ are studied, along with the progress of Ernst away from the Surrealist movement before World War II. At the commencement of the war, a trying era began for Ernst of imprisonments at various stages in France for his German citizenship and as a result of false accusations, spending a few months in a concentration camp, which led to his subsequent difficult, but finally successful move to America with the help of colleague and third wife Peggy Guggenheim and the New York art scene. Here the program details his first Surrealist Exhibition in New York and his invention of what is now known as action painting, all received with great critical acclaim, and his following career in New York, during which time he married the painter, Dorothea Tanning. Their move to Arizona, to live and work in a ‘landscape of the minds eye’ signalled a time of detachment from many of his peers and a fascination with Native American culture and crafts and the rythms of the landscape that he had painted before seeing and that manifested a great influence in his works of the time. In the 1950s, his return to Europe was met with little recognition, but following the receipt of the Grand Prix of Venice in 1954, his acclaim saw an establishment of his freedom to experiment with his progression of interests in painting and sculpture once again. The program closes with an analysis of his work at this stage where his final settlement in the ‘Garden of France’ with Dorothea is discussed with reference to the hopeful nuances of his later series of paintings that studied the idea of the cage, and most symbolically, an empty cage from which a bird had escaped.

results.title: Max's money troubles
results.creator_credit: Chris Adshead, Timothy Read, Australia. Department of the Attorney-General and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A humorous dramatisation about the implications of declaring oneself bankrupt. Max is an ordinary family man, who is in deep financial difficulty. His debts far exceed his ability to pay. We follow Max through the steps he must take to solve his seemingly unsolvable problem. He appears to find an ideal expedient in declaring himself bankrupt, but through counselling Max learns of the likely consequences of this and that it should only ever be a last resort. Written by Donald Crombie.
